image.altText: A man, walking at the front of a large crowd outdoors, holding a framed picture of another man.

props.synopsis: Specifics about how Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr were killed on Tuesday are scarce, but one thing is certain: the two high-profile hits will further destabilise the Middle East.

title.children: Two global assassination plots in 24 hours: Is this the day that changes the Middle East?

image.altText: Foreign minister Penny Wong faces the media in Adelaide. 2024-04-06 10:04:00

props.synopsis: Australians have been urged to leave Lebanon immediately as the foreign minister emphasises the Beirut airport could close if the situation worsens.

title.children: Foreign Minister Penny Wong warns Australians in Lebanon to leave immediately

image.altText: A man in a store, wearing a cap and bumbag.

props.synopsis: The FBI, AFP and Malaysian police have all failed to charge Adrian Katong. In the meantime the phishing syndicate operator is leading a life of luxury and becoming more brazen in his operations that have taken millions of dollars from Australians.

title.children: This phisher has taken millions from Australians. He continues to operate brazenly

image.altText: Alanna Kennedy of Australia reacts after losing to the USA during the Paris Olympic Games

props.synopsis: After three underwhelming performances saw them crash out at the group stage for the first time since 2000, the Matildas' Olympic campaign must be a reality check for the Australian game.

title.children: Matildas' Olympic exit is the reality check Australia has been bracing for

image.altText: A close-up of Australian canoeist Jessica Fox smiling at the camera while holding her Olympic gold medal.

props.synopsis: Jess Fox's Olympian parents say the Australian's magnificent C1 gold to add to her K1 title earlier in the Paris Olympics will not be bettered in the sport of canoe slalom.

title.children: Jess Fox rewrites the history books in Paris with 'the most remarkable thing she's ever done'

image.altText: Jess Fox, Favour Ofili and Iga Swiatek

props.synopsis: Jess Fox's C1 win proves to be eight years in the making, Nigeria's officials are in hot water over a horrible error ahead of the 100m sprint, and the best women's tennis player in the world finds herself in an opponent's crosshairs.

title.children: Olympic quick hits: Incredible picture shows Fox is an idol, blunder denies Nigerian track star, and Iga Swiatek blasted over 'fakeness'

image.altText: A man in a suit sitting and speaking, with his arms raised, gesturing

props.synopsis: Donald Trump uses an appearance at a gathering of Black journalists to suggest his election opponent, Kamala Harris, has switched racial identities from Indian to Black.

title.children: Donald Trump suggests Kamala Harris 'happened to turn Black'

image.altText: Silhouettes of five people are coloured and laid out in a graphic.

props.synopsis: The disability community bared its soul at the royal commission. Now the initial response has been unveiled, some are wondering whether the pain was really worth it, write Nas Campanella and Evan Young.

title.children: The disability royal commission demanded extensive change. Are the government responses big enough?

image.altText: A view of the harbour.

props.synopsis: The Beijing-controlled government in Hong Kong is luring mainland Chinese to live in the city to shore up the city's faltering economy.

title.children: In a tiny $3m flat, I'm witnessing China's plans to replace the Hong Kongers who fled

image.altText: Allegra Spender

props.synopsis: The crossbenchers say criminality in the industry is worsening housing affordability and eroding productivity.

title.children: Crossbenchers want federal money withheld until states tackle construction 'corruption'

image.altText: A regional express airplane

props.synopsis: Rex's risky gamble to compete with major airlines on intercity routes may see it back where it started, albeit with greater financial problems.

title.children: Rex chose to gamble during the pandemic. It will take weeks to know how much its lost

image.altText: Felicity Chafer-Smith The Torch artwork

props.synopsis: Programs like The Torch in Victoria want to break the cycle of incarceration for First Nations people.

title.children: With Indigenous incarceration increasing, community-led groups say they've got answers

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks towards the camera with other people surrounding him.

props.synopsis: According to the Productivity Commission, five of 19 Closing the Gap targets are currently 'on track'. That's where the good news ends.

title.children: The new inflation figures brought relief for Albanese, but another set of numbers were depressing reading

image.altText: Kyle Chalmers stands tall with his silver medal, with an Australian flag visible behind him

props.synopsis: Kyle Chalmers comes in second behind the fastest 100m freestyle time ever recorded, but his career of perseverance and Olympic excellence should serve as inspiration for the Australian sprint duo who missed out earlier in the night.

title.children: Chalmers beaten only by brilliance as Australian sprint queens rue one that got away

image.altText: A man celebrates winning a gold medal with his arms wide on the top of the podium

props.synopsis: Kyle Chalmers believes he was bested by a clean racer. But that did little to satiate Pan who has accused the Aussie star of a poolside snub.

title.children: 'I trust that': Bested Chalmers confident Chinese record-holder swam drug-free race

image.altText: Leon Marchand holds up his hand

props.synopsis: Nobody has ever won gold medals in breaststroke and butterfly events at the same Games, let alone on the same night within two hours of each other. But there has never been someone like Léon Marchand.

title.children: Doing something that hasn't been done in 48 years, Marchand is proving to be the fairytale story of the Paris Olympics

image.altText: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, (R), the alleged mastermind of the September 11 attacks, speaks with his defence lawyer

props.synopsis: The letter to families of the September 11 victims says the guilty pleas could be entered as soon as next week or within the next few months.

title.children: Man accused of plotting September 11 attacks reaches plea deal alongside two accomplices

image.altText: A composite image showing Linday Reynolds on the left and Brittany Higgins on the right

props.synopsis: With mediation attempts and extensions of olive branches falling flat, Senator Linda Reynolds's defamation trial against Brittany Higgins and her partner David Sharaz will kick off tomorrow.

title.children: What to expect from the defamation trial Linda Reynolds has brought against Brittany Higgins and David Sharaz

image.altText: A white man screams in the face of a police officer wearing riot gear.

props.synopsis: The Merseyside Police force says the teenager, who has not been named because of his age, faces three counts of murder and 10 counts of attempted murder over the attack.

title.children: Police charge 17-year-old with three counts of murder over Southport stabbing

image.altText: The members of The 1975 dressed in suits against a white background.

props.synopsis: Authorities in Kuala Lumpur halted the three-day Good Vibes Festival in 2023 after videos showed The 1975's frontman Matty Healy kissing his band mate.

title.children: UK band The 1975 sued for $3.76 million over 'gay kiss' that got festival cancelled

image.altText: An open for inspection sign at a Brisbane apartment, behind it people are entering a building

props.synopsis: Australian house prices rise 0.5 per cent in July, despite Melbourne, Hobart and Darwin recording a fall in values during the past three months, according to new data released by CoreLogic.

title.children: What July's house price data tells us about where values are headed

image.altText: A graphic image of Kamala Harris on a mobile phone screen with coconut palms and a lime green background.

props.synopsis: A humorous antidote to serious news, a way of getting young people involved in political discussions, or a threat to democracy — young people talk about memes.

title.children: Are politicians fair game when it comes to memes?

image.altText: Eddie Ockenden in action playing hockey

props.synopsis: Here's everything that's going to be happening on day six of the Olympic Games.

title.children: Olympics schedule day six: Kookaburras take on New Zealand and Aussie golfers hit the green

image.altText: Mollie O'Callaghan after the women's 100m freestyle final

props.synopsis: Mollie O'Callaghan says she needs to "suck it up" after being stunned in the women's 100m freestyle final in Paris.

title.children: 'Really nervous': Mollie O'Callaghan reveals anxiety issue after being denied medal in 100m freestyle final

image.altText: Caitlin Parker pumps one fist in the air as the referee holds her other hand and the hand of her opponent.

props.synopsis: Caitlin Parker says she believes the approval of two boxers at the Olympics who had failed gender eligibility tests is "incredibly dangerous", while coach Santiago Nieva says it's "not black and white".

title.children: 'This issue is not black and white': Australian boxing captain and coach disagree over gender eligibility decisions

image.altText: The Fawkner McDonald's restaurant at sunrise.

props.synopsis: Global giant McDonald's has recorded its first drop in sales in nearly four years, as customers cut back on spending amid a cost-of-living crunch.

title.children: McDonald's sales fall as inflation-weary customers turn away from fast food

image.altText: Two young indigenous women sit on a bench outdoors chatting.

props.synopsis: One in 10 young people who responded to Mission Australia's 2023 Youth Survey faced homelessness in the past year, as the issue becomes more challenging due to the housing crisis.

title.children: Refuge hopping and sleeping under bridges: One in 10 teens polled faced homelessness last year

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A tech rally on Wall Street has sent Australian stocks higher, while the Federal Reserve has left US interest rates unchanged but indicated it could begin easing monetary policy in September if inflation cools. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises, US Fed signals upcoming rate cut

image.altText: Black and white image of woman with long dark hair staring directly into camera

props.synopsis: When Hayley Campbell was just a child, she had an encounter with death that began a lifelong curiosity about what happens when we die.

title.children: This journalist spent two years working with the invisible people behind the death industry

image.altText: Ismail Haniyeh puts his right index finger across his stubbled chin as he tilts his head down slightly and looks forwards.

props.synopsis: With the killing in Iran of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh, the possibility that all key players have wanted to avoid — a full-scale war between Israel and Hezbollah — is now closer than ever.

title.children: The assassination that could bring full-scale war — and devastation to three countries

image.altText: A construction crew working on a home build on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: As hundreds of West Australians wait for Ronnie Michel-Elhaj's failing building company Nicheliving to finish their homes, his wife's luxury build continues.

title.children: Building firm Nicheliving has been deregistered, but luxury home build of company boss's wife continues apace

image.altText: A woman lying in bed at night looking at her smartphone, with the phone and a lamp casting a soft light on her face.

props.synopsis: Sleep displacement is the time between when you decide to go to bed and decide to go to sleep. Tech can play a role in lengthening that time, but it's not always a bad thing, experts say.

title.children: Doomscrolling before bed? Here’s how sleep displacement affects our health

image.altText: A marble statue of a man throwing a discus with a modern stadium backdrop.

props.synopsis: Painting, sculpture, architecture, literature and music all once were Olympic categories — but the medals have been stricken from the official national medal counts.

title.children: The Olympics used to award medals to paintings, sculptures and even music. It didn't work out.
